message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The circular patches of complete hair loss, associated pruritus and burning sensation, and the histologic findings of peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate suggest the most likely diagnosis is Alopecia Areata. Tinea capitis would have scaliness and Wood’s lamp fluorescence. Telogen effluvium would have diffuse hair shedding, and androgenic alopecia would have thinning hair in the pattern of androgens.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the hair loss and the biopsy findings suggest alopecia areata. Tinea capitis and telogen effluvium typically present with patches of hair loss, but do not have the same biopsy findings. Androgenic alopecia typically presents with a patterned hair loss, not circular patches.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of multiple smooth, circular patches of complete hair loss on the scalp, associated with pruritus and a burning sensation, and the presence of inflammatory infiltrate surrounding anagen follicles resembling a swarm of bees, is consistent with the diagnosis of alopecia areata. Tinea capitis would show epidermal inflammation or erythema, and fluorescence might be detected under Wood’s lamp. Telogen effluvium and androgenic alopecia would not show the characteristic peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate seen in alopecia areata.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question, specifically the smooth circular patches of complete hair loss with associated pruritus and burning sensation, suggest alopecia areata. The peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate surrounding anagen follicles, resembling a swarm of bees seen on biopsy, is characteristic of alopecia areata. The other options, tinea capitis, telogen effluvium, and androgenic alopecia, do not fit the presentation described in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of multiple smooth, circular patches of complete hair loss with pruritus and burning sensation, and the presence of peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate surrounding anagen follicles resembling a swarm of bees points to the diagnosis of Alopecia areata. None of the other options provide such specific characteristics.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy findings suggest that the most likely diagnosis is Alopecia areata. Tinea capitis will cause scaly lesions and fluorescence under Wood’s lamp. Telogen effluvium and Androgenic alopecia do not typically have associated pruritus and burning sensation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of smooth, circular patches of complete hair loss on the scalp with pruritus and burning sensation suggests Alopecia areata. The peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate surrounding anagen follicles is a characteristic finding in Alopecia areata. Tinea capitis would show epidermal inflammation and erythema, and Telogen effluvium and Androgenic alopecia do not present with complete hair loss in patches.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The smooth, circular patches and peribulbar inflammatory infiltrate are classic symptoms of alopecia areata, which is an autoimmune disorder that results in hair loss. Tinea capitis would show inflammation and erythema, and Telogen effluvium and Androgenic alopecia do not show circumscribed patches of hair loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The smooth, circular patches with peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate surrounding anagen follicles suggest alopecia areata. Tinea capitis would cause scaling and erythema. Telogen effluvium and androgenic alopecia do not present with circular patches of hair loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of circular patches of complete hair loss with associated pruritus and burning sensation suggests Alopecia areata. The peribulbar lymphocytic inflammatory infiltrate is a characteristic finding. Tinea capitis would have epidermal inflammation or erythema, and a positive Wood’s lamp finding. Telogen effluvium would present with diffuse hair loss. Androgenic alopecia would have a gradual onset and progressive thinning of hair over the crown and frontal scalp.
